# Draft:The Great Battle of Kairouan (695 AD)

The Battle of Great Kairouan is a fictional battle said to have taken place around 695 AD between the Umayyad Caliphate and the united Berber tribes of North Africa under the leadership of Dihya, also known as the Kahina. Despite being heavily outnumbered, the Berbers achieved a decisive victory that led to the collapse of Umayyad control in Ifriqiya.
Background
The Berber resistance had been growing steadily due to political oppression and heavy taxation by the Umayyad administration. Dihya, a legendary warrior queen, united various tribes to launch a counter-offensive against the Umayyads after their occupation of Kairouan.
The Battle
With 40,000 fighters, the Berbers ambushed the larger Umayyad force of 100,000 near Kairouan. Using superior knowledge of terrain and guerrilla tactics, the Berbers inflicted severe losses. The Umayyad lines collapsed after several days of fighting.
Aftermath
The Umayyad army retreated toward Barqa (modern-day Libya), and Kairouan fell under Berber control. Dihya ruled the region for several years before the Umayyads launched a renewed campaign.
